Thanks for posting that, Dave.  What you've written is very nice.  I 
may even agree with most of what you've said, based solely on my 
faith in you as a bright person and self-described Master Software 
Craftsman.  But, I was hoping to get more of an answer to my 
question.  I'll be honest, based on the description you've provided 
of this approach, I find it really hard to determine if what you're 
talking about is either a) Genuine Refinement or b) Needless 
Complication.  Please don't take offense to this criticism.  I'll be 
the first to admit that I'm here to learn.  I think we can all say 
the same.

Now, I like to keep things simple:  I have a Java class.  It lives in 
a file.  The file lives in a source code repository.  It has 
corresponding test code that tests anything that could possibly break 
in the class.  Sometimes I check the Java class out of the repository 
and add stuff to it.  Since I practice TDD, more than likely I also 
need to add something to the corresponding test code.  When I'm done, 
I check the Java class back in, along with the corresponding test 
code.  Cruisecontrol detects this and automatically runs a build on 
the build server.  If the code passes all the tests, I go home and 
life is good because I know I'll get a paycheck the next week to pay 
rent and buy food.

Now, based on those very simple real world requirements, just exactly 
what is it that makes your approach so superior that you will 
immediately discount all others as inadequate?

I know, I know, it's in the newsletter and the forthcoming book.  
That's fabulous.  But you're preaching to the TDD converted here and 
we have found our own ways, based first on the information currently 
available and second on our own experience.  I beleive TDD has 
gathered quite a bit of momentum by now and if you have any chance of 
influencing its direction you need to provide a little more than just 
self-referential justification for your approach.  (Dave Astels: "My 
technique is the best because that's what it says in my literature.  
My literature proposes a certain technique because it's the best 
technique.  My technique is the best because that's what it says in 
my literature.  My literature proposes a certain technique because 
it's the best technique.  Blah, blah, blah.")

You say, "This will help us write and organize groups of tests that 
are simpler, cleaner, more understandable, and more maintainable."

These are all noble goals for an approach to TDD.  Would you care to 
elaborate on just why you believe you have achieved these goals?

Mike
